The reality is that we're

How do we deal with this

Well, we increase the amount
of data that's out there
to address these questions.

As we think about trying
to conserve species,
the first thing you need to understand
is where did these things occur now
and where did they occur in the past?
We have literally millions of specimens
that document where species were found.

And what we now need is
lots of data that tell us
where species are found today

so we can look at how ranges
are shifting through time.

The question is how do you
go about getting tons of data
on where species are found today?

And one of the exciting
things that's really happened
in sort of the last 10 to 15 years

is that the opportunity
to get those sorts of data
has changed dramatically

as a result of what people
often call community science
or call citizen science.

There are currently tens
of thousands of people
all around the world on iNaturalist

contributing observations,
making identifications,
something on the order
of 85 million species occurrence records.

Huge data set that's allowing
us to do statistical analyses

that no individual researcher
would've ever even been able

to come close to creating
a data set like this.
